executive_summary: Maryland demonstrates solid appreciation for its public servants, earning the highest score among the five states initially assessed. The state excels in workforce stabilityâ€”employees stay an average of 12 years and turnover is low at 8%. Strong benefits including a defined-benefit pension, generous health coverage, and ample paid leave partially offset salaries that lag private-sector comparisons.

Massachusetts maintains a highly stable workforce with exceptional retention (91%) and 15-year average tenure, supported by comprehensive benefits and substantial technology investments ($946 per employee). The Commonwealth's cost-of-living-adjusted salaries compete well nationally despite base wages lagging private-sector levels.

Washington State provides highly competitive compensation and invests heavily in technology modernization ($7,600 per employee), demonstrating strong commitment to equipping employees with modern tools. The state's defined-benefit pension, 85% employer-paid health premiums, and generous leave policies support solid workforce retention (91%).

Virginia leads all assessed states in competitive compensation, with public employees earning 122% of private-sector wages and receiving excellent benefits including a hybrid pension with cost-of-living adjustments and 88-98% employer-paid health coverage. The Commonwealth also maintains strong formal recognition infrastructure with multiple award programs and official Public Service Week observances.

North Carolina's strongest dimension is competitive compensation, with state employees earning slightly above private-sector levels (103%) and receiving solid benefits including a defined-benefit pension and comprehensive leave policies. Cost-of-living adjustments further strengthen purchasing power.
